utterances.sentences: Up next, Trace Gallagher is going to highlight some of the tightest Senate races and then we're going to talk to Arizona Republican senatorial candidate Martha McSally. Stay there.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: All right. We're just four days away from the midterms and some of these races are in dead heat including right here in Arizona. In moments, we'll talk with Republican Senate candidate Martha McSally. But first, Fox's Trace Gallagher joins us now with an important update. Trace?

utterances.speaker: TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Hi, Laura. If you look at just the Fox News polls over the past two months, the Indiana Senate races is seen a significant shift in the numbers. In September, GOP challenger Mike Braun was up by two points over Democratic incumbent Joe Donnelly. In early October, that flipped and Donnelly was up by two. Now Donnelly has increased the lead to seven points, but don't write off Mike Braun just yet because according to the Real Clear Politics average Donnelly is up by less than one point. Meaning this race still appears to be a dead heat. In the show me state Senate race no matter what poles you look at it is a tossup. The RCP average has Republican challenger Josh Hawley leading by two points over Missouri Democratic incumbent Claire McCaskill and that's within the margin of error. The Fox News poll has them deadlocked at 43 percent each. And it's been that way for the past month. And we should know that polls also show Missouri Democrats appear to be more interested in the election than Missouri Republicans even though 54 percent of likely Missouri voters approve of the president's job performance. The Florida Senate race seems to change with the seasons. For most of the spring Democratic incumbent Senator Bill Nelson held a very steady leave over Florida Republican Governor Rick Scott. Then came summer and Rick Scott took the lead, but now leaves have changed and so have the polls. According to the RCP average, Bill Nelson is back on top by two points. It appears Rick Scott could use a heat wave. Finally, the Arizona where Fox News poll showed Democrat Krysten Sinema and Republican Martha McSally dead even at 46 percent each. That's a bad trend for Sinema who was up by two points in early October and up three in September, although the Real Clear Politics average still has Sinema by just over half point. But all of these polls were taken before Green party candidate Angela Greene dropped out and endorse Krysten Sinema. And we should note Sinema was a green party activist but has tried very hard to distance herself from her past. Laura?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: All right. Thanks so much, Trace. And joining me now to discuss that latest toss up that Trace just mentioned is a woman vying to become its next senator, Republican Martha McSally, of Arizona. Congresswoman, thanks for being here tonight. I want to start with immigration. We just completed a focus group so important for the voters of the state. How is your view on immigration different from your opponent's? REP. MARTHA MCSALLY, RARIZ.: Well, it's like night and day. I represent a border district. I chair the border security subcommittee and I'm leading working with President Trump to make sure we build the wall, secure the border, close these crazy loopholes that are being taken advantage of every single day, end chain migration, to visa lottery, and you know, move forward in a way that is protecting Americans. My opponent was actually an activist helping people cross illegally in her past and even though she had amazing political makeover trying to fool the voters here, she's voted to support sanctuary cities. And on really important vote here that's meaningful in Arizona is she voted against Grant's Law. This was named after Grant--

Grant was shot point-blank by somebody who shouldn't haven't here and should have been held until they were deported. utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Absolutely not, no, it's not. Look, we have cartels that are trafficking people and drugs through our communities right now. And goes on to say, "and Trump simply cannot stop them from legally doing so or using the military or anyone."

We work really hard on this and with President Trump to close these loopholes, to make sure that people can't just show up and demand to be in our country and be released into the interior of the United States. This is happening every single day here in Arizona. Hundreds of little mini caravans are taking advantage of this and now they're trying to sue the president? This has to stop. We must secure our border now.

You know, we pick up North Dakota, we don't want to cancel it out in Arizona, right. This is for everybody, not just in Arizona. Please go to McSallyforSenate.com. We need people to contribute. But we need people to get off the sidelines in Arizona. So, tell your friends and family to get out to the polls to make sure that we hold this seat. This is about the direction of our country.

I'm working very closely with him on so many things. We're building our military, securing our border. Look at the economy. I mean, it's amazing. We want to keep things going and that's what this election is about.

OK.

There's never been a better time to be a small business owner, to be entering the workforce for the first time, never a better time. Today the news came out, 3.5 percent, wage increase which is the largest we've had since 2009. Unemployment is down to a 1967 low which is fantastic across all economic strata. How many of you here today give Trump credit for this economic revival on the wage increase? Raise you hand. You haven't spoken, another young person. I want to hear from the youth.

utterances.speaker: TEANA LONG, DEMOCRAT
utterances.sentences: I go to school up north. I'm in a small town. And the wage increases have really affected our small town, because, like I said, it's very small. So it's really hard not only to find jobs because small businesses can't afford to pay its workers, but it's really hard -- a lot of companies are going out of business and we are losing a lot of really valuable companies that are really important to our market.

utterances.speaker: DEBE CAMPOS FLEENOR, REPUBLICAN
utterances.sentences: I am a small business owner, Latino owned, woman owned, and actually the taxes from Trump have done very well for our small business.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Tax cuts?

utterances.speaker: FLEENOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: What have they resulted in?

utterances.speaker: FLEENOR
utterances.sentences: Right here, $1,200. So that's pretty good. It gives me the opportunity to pay my employees the wage increase that was forced upon me, instead of cutting hours.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: How many Democrats here, those of you who are Democrats, are you concerned that the House of Representatives being turned over to Democrats would upset the economic recovery? Raise your hand. Even if you voted Democrat, are you concerned about the economy being adversely affected?

utterances.speaker: PILAR RUIZ, DEMOCRAT
utterances.sentences: I am. From southern Arizona, I'm a neighbor with Raul Grijalva, district three. And that is one of the poorest districts in the country. And he is a Democrat and I am a Democrat, but you know what, for me it's not always about party line. It's about what are you doing for the people. And him and his daughter have hurt southern Arizona, Adelita Grijalva, more than any other politicians in Arizona in my opinion. So that regards, I don't want that man in office. We need Republican in district three to win that race because -- I know it's not going to happen but it needs to happen because that district is extremely poor. There is no economic growth. There is no nothing.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: How many of you here will miss Jeff Flake? Raise your hand. How many of you here will miss Jeff Flake in the U.S. Senate?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Only his sanity.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: He has about an 18 percent approval rating, but that's OK. While we are talking about Arizona, this is what Kyrsten Sinema, of course the Democrat who wants to be your next senator, said about the state she hopes to represent. Let's listen.

utterances.speaker: KYRSTEN SIMENA, (D-AZ) SENATE CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: So all around the world people know what's happening in Arizona, and not in a good way. We're not famous in a good way. We're kind of like in a Lindsay Lohan kind of famous way. The states are the laboratories of democracies, and in my state of Arizona it's clearly the meth lab of democracy. Republicans get a free ride when they call the Tea Party something other than what they are. And we have to say no, no, Tea Party Republicans, all the same thing. They're all crazy.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.sentences: To the Democrats in the room, put your hands up. If that offends you in any way.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It depends. I couldn't really hear it very well. I have a lot of disagreements with Kyrsten Sinema over the years, and I'm not a good friend of hers, but she is 10 times better than McSally on issues right from the top to the bottom.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Now, the further removed we are from the Kavanaugh confirmation fight, the more the baseless charges against him unravel. Ann Coulter is here, she will be with us later, to tell us about another criminal referral involving a Kavanaugh accuser. And up next, when Hollywood comes out to stump for Democrats, does anyone care? And wait until you hear what our focus group tells us. Don't go anywhere.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It probably will put a fire under me, especially with all the misogyny going on.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: The Democratic candidates are bringing out the big guns. Celebrities are making ads, knocking on doors, as White House pushes back.

utterances.speaker: OPRAH WINFREY, TALK SHOW HOST
utterances.sentences: You get a vote, and you get a vote, and you get a vote.

utterances.speaker: WILL FERRELL, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: Hi. It's Will Ferrell. I'm here in Kennesaw State. Of course home of the owls. We're trying to get people to vote here for Stacey Abrams.

utterances.speaker: MIKE PENCE, U.S. VICE PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: I would like to remind Stacey and Oprah and Will Ferrell, I'm kind of a big deal, too. This ain't Hollywood. This is Georgia.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: OK, so does trotting out Hollywood heavyweights actually move voters? We asked our focus group. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: How many people here in Arizona would you have your vote affected one way or the another by a celebrity's endorsement? Raise your hand. No one, either side.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.sentences: Alex, you are one of the people they are targeting, young people. Your reaction to that?

utterances.speaker: ALEX PHILLIPS, REPUBLICAN
utterances.sentences: As much fun as I had seen Kanye West and Donald Trump in the White House --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIPS
utterances.sentences: -- with the hats on, I'm not going to base my political views off that. You can get your mileage off of it, but at the end of the day you should probably not make that the be-all, end-all.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Take a look at this brand-new political ad directed by a brilliant film director and actress, Jodie Foster.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: If somebody asked you what do you care about, what would you say?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Losing your health care?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Equal pay?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Equal rights?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: What really, honestly matter to you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: If basic human rights matter, then vote.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: If women's rights really are human rights, then vote.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Don't.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Lose.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hope.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.sentences: To the ladies here, would that ad in any way motivate you to go to the polls? Show of hands. Yes, if it would. In the back, why?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: If I wasn't going to vote or had no motivation, it would probably put a fire under me, especially with all the misogyny going on.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: What is the most important issue for all of you, both parties, no parties, on Tuesday, the most important issue?

utterances.speaker: PATRICK BRAY, REPUBLICAN
utterances.sentences: I think for Arizona in general right now, I think the top issue is clearly immigration. And it's driven by the caravan that is on his way here. And I think we talked about it, but there's a twofold there with immigration. There is the regulatory system that's broken, but there's a border security issue that's also broken, and that's why you have to see the military making sure we send a clear signal that we are just not going to let people in our back door.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Health care for all. That's the biggest issue. People need -- how many -- 35 million people are without health care.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Should illegal immigrants, should they get free health care in the United States? Raise your hand.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. Well, you'll have to pay for it through --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Free college?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Free college.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: All right, let's go. You better make a lot of money.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.sentences: How many people support that idea, free college, free health care for illegal immigrants.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Do African-Americans or veterans all get free college? We have 300,000 veterans living on the street, homeless veterans on the street tonight.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: There are 60 percent taxes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Medicare for all is not free. I'm on Medicare.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: There won't be any Medicare dollars for you, my friend.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's not free.

utterances.speaker: FLEENOR
utterances.sentences: -- of us are working to pay taxes. We are supporting those people whether they are illegal or whatever. I can't work anymore. I can't pay any more taxes. And 47 percent are on the dole. And how much greater does that number need to go before we become a socialist --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Hold on, guys. While we're talking about that, birthright citizenship, should children born -- neither parent is an American citizen, neither parent is here illegally as a worker or anything like that, but just illegal immigrant in the United States has a child. Should that child immediately become an American citizen?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Of course, it's the 14th Amendment.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's in the Constitution.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: So all -- so 300,000 of the illegal immigrants should automatically become --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: All right, it got really raucous there. We could have done a whole on this. I want to do more of these, so much fun. Another Kavanaugh accuser, by the way, facing potentially severe criminal punishment over a false claim against the now associate justice of the Supreme Court. Ann Coulter is here next to break it all down, and what it could mean for the midterms.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Brett Kavanaugh might be sitting on the Supreme Court, but the fallout from his confirmation battle is far from over. Just hours ago, Senator Chuck Grassley made another criminal referral to the Department of Justice concerning an unnamed accuser who made rape allegations against Kavanaugh. The unidentified woman admits she, quote, "just wanted to get attention," and that it was, quote, "a ploy." And joining me now with her reaction is bestselling author and commentator Ann Coulter. Ann, the convention here is that Republican enthusiasm over the Kavanaugh confirmation was waning. What do you think with stories like this in the last few days before the vote?

utterances.speaker: ANN COULTER, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: Liberals are crazy, and it's good for voters to be reminded of this. We've been going through a two-year tantrum. But this one really takes the cake. That letter she wrote reads like, Penthouse letters, the detail of this gang rape. And first it's just written anonymously. The handwriting could have been written by a man. It's sort of suspicious, a lot of capital letters. It's like a hostage note. And then this woman in Kentucky claims that she was the one who wrote it, gives her name. The Senate Judiciary Committee does a little research and finds out she doesn't live either in Washington, D.C., or Oceanside, California, which is where the original anonymous hostage letter claimed to come from. She's from Kentucky. She's and several decades older than judge, not justice Kavanaugh, and has a history of being a liberal activist. Her quotes to the committee were hilarious. It was just, yes, well, it was in the news. I wanted to get attention. He had to be stopped.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Ann, isn't this good, though, to make these people pay? And it reminds me of this leak that came out of the Feinstein office. I've been talking about this since it happened. This must be investigated and it must be pursued. Republicans are going to hold onto the House, unless something really wacky happens. This can't be dropped by Lindsey Graham when he takes over the committee. I think you've got to go in. I want everybody's emails, I want everybody's texts, and I want to know who leaked that Blasey Ford letter. I want to know who did that. It was a travesty what happened to him.

utterances.speaker: COULTER
utterances.sentences: Yes. What often happens in these cases is our side, OK, he's on the Supreme Court, let's move on. Let's be good guys, because that will be repaid by good behavior from the left. No, we will never get good behavior from the left. And whether it's a Duke lacrosse or that UVA gal or mattress girl up in Columbia, there have just been all of these fake rate allegations, which happen to be the fake allegations made against judge, now Justice Kavanaugh. And the false accuser doesn't get prosecuted. In the Duke lacrosse case, she went on to stop her boyfriend to death. No, there has to be some sort of repercussions of making false allegations of rape. This was a very serious allegation, not particularly plausible. But of course these cases need to be pursued. One other thing, I think this is why contrary to what everybody else will be telling President Trump, the next nominee he gets to the Supreme Court, I don't care whom he is replacing, it has to be a man because we now know what the left's playbook is. They did at 29 years ago to Justice Thomas, they did it again to now to Justice Kavanaugh. People are going to say, pick a woman, pick a woman. What, because liberal love women so much? They love you and me, Laura, they love Sarah Palin.

utterances.speaker: COULTER
utterances.sentences: But if they have another false allegation, I don't think anybody is going to buy it in the next few years. It absolutely should be a man.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I think it should be the best, I don't care what your gender is, the best and most conservative, judicially conservative pick, whoever that is. But doing the bean counting, Ann, never works for conservatives. You've been way ahead of the curve on that issue, and obviously immigration and so many others. Thank you so much, Ann Coulter, here on the "The Laura Ingraham Show and on the "Ingraham Angle," of course. I still have radio on the brain. When we come back, a preview of my Monday night closing argument, next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Martha McSally, good luck. You're going to be singing the national anthem tomorrow at the ASU football game. I'll be there. I'll be watching. And her opponent Kyrsten Sinema is going to be taking part in the coin toss. And on Monday, I'm going to deliver my closing arguments to all you voters across the country. utterances.speaker: LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: I'm Laura Ingraham. And this is "The Ingraham Angle," live once again from Arizona tonight. We're just four days away from the critical midterm elections. And there are only two things that currently hang in the balance. An economy as evidenced by today's job reports. It's a roaring, my friends, and an immigration policy that makes sense. And my simple message is this. Let's not stop success, America. Since we're here in the Grand Canyon state we thought it was really important to talk to some of the voters here. So I'm talking about people of different political affiliations, different races different, walks of life to hear firsthand what really matters most to them ahead of Tuesday's elections. Now these are the voters who are going to decide in the neck and neck Arizona race now between Martha McSally, Republican, and Democrat Kyrsten Sinema. We're going to McSally just ahead. But first we want to hear from the voters themselves. We started this evening with the pressing issue of immigration and how illegals have affected this border state. Raymond Arroyo joined me for the questioning of this group. Here's part one.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I want to bring with an issue that is front and center right now and that's the issue of immigration. Now there are multiple caravans barreling toward our southern border, and as border state here in Arizona a lot of the migrants could end up in your own backyard. So, show of hands here. How many of you think we should welcome all members of the caravan despite evidence that there are criminals within the group? Raise your hand. All members of the caravan.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I don't think there's criminals in the group.

utterances.speaker: RAYMOND ARROYO, DIRECTOR AND LEAD ANCHOR, EWTN
utterances.utterance: You don't think there are ny criminals?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: No. I don't think there are criminal, there are women and children who are trying to get away from fear and military dictators and all kinds of other problems in their countries and they're looking for- -

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Actually, Griff Jenkins was our correspondent down and he's been with the caravan for a number of days. He interviewed various members of the caravan and this is what he found out on Sunday. Let's watch.

utterances.speaker: GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Are you willing to break the law to get back to the United States?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: She says he wants to apply to pardon for the felony he committed.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.utterance: Can you ask him exactly what happened?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Number three.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: A third-degree felony.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Attempted murder.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Dan, your reaction.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: My reaction is that most of these women and children and families were coming here for asylum and they are doing it the right way. That you have to go to a port of entry, you have to turn yourself in at a port of entry and you have to apply for asylum. Now if they don't fit asylum then they have to go back. But if they meet the criteria for asylum, they're not breaking the law, they should be entered, let them.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Now listen to what President Trump has to say about the way women feel about this caravan.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: I don't want them in our country and women don't want them in our country. Women want security. Men don't want them in our country, but the women do not want them. Women want security.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Terry, I saw you nodding your head or shaking your head a minute ago.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I don't care if nobody is a criminal. Have some respect for this country and do it the legal way. I'm a lifelong Democrat. I switch over for Trump just to vote for him. I've always felt this way. If we these people come in this way it's going to set precedents. There is suffering everywhere in the world. Where do we draw the line? Charity starts at home. Let's take care of our own, first and foremost. Then we do it the legal way, not illegally.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Laura, I see Roy sitting next to Terry chomping it a bit. Go ahead, Roy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I mean, to hear Trump say that women don't want the caravan to come in. I'm not sure number one the women don't want to be around Donald Trump. But first and foremost, I will say that, you know, let's got to the process. Let's process each case by case. If was a proper system of immigration in place then we can properly vet those that will try to enter the country and decipher who's a criminal and who was seeking asylum.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Julie, you wanted to say what?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: There is a system how to come to this country. I am an immigrant and I did it the right way. You file your paperwork, to get approved. You come here. It's as simple as that.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, here's problem is that right now our system is being gamed. That's what a lot of people view that the asylum system, it's a good thing that allow people to come in for asylum for certain credible fears. Fear of religious persecution, fear of ethnic cleansing, true fears of persecution for, you know, political outlook. But what's happening for most of these migrants. And we had the Mexican ambassador and the Guatemalan interior minister on the other night on the Angle and they both said that most of these migrants overwhelmingly their economic. They're coming because hundreds of millions of people around the world. America is a great place to live. It's better than most countries in the world, and so they want to come there. Let's go to Sergio.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Laura, I want to, you know, what the media isn't showing is that their passing live feeds of what's happening in Mexico with this caravan and the caravan is assaulting police officers and they're throwing rocks and they're leaving trash and they're tearing apart the country of Mexico. You have people there, their own Mexican residents that are living there, that are saying go back to your countries, stop tearing up ours.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: But there was also a feeling in there, you have a good and being welcome in different parts of the community.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: But they're taking this mindset and they're coming and they're bringing it down to this border.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Yvonne on the top there.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I'm an immigrant to this country and I came here legally. It took me 10 years to get my citizenship and I also worked in the healthcare industry. And you know they look at this caravan. This is an organized group. I really felt an invasion of our country. I mean, this is an organized caravan. They have people that have trucks, they are hauling these people on the freeway, you know, and then they look at the caravan, they are finding that 80 percent of it are men and less than 20 percent are women and children.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Again, the officials that are monitoring this, the Mexican officials, the Guatemalan officials both that we've talk to and that we've interviewed have confirmed them. They are overwhelmingly able-bodied working age men, women and children being put in the front. And the description of one of -- from one of the officials was almost like a human shield.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: That's a fact. That's not a political opinion no matter what people think about immigration, that's fine, but it's not political opinion. That's a fact. And I have a question, how many of you here and you're all of different backgrounds and political persuasions, object to the use of the word invasion? Raise your hand. So that's about half, about split. How many of the people who object to the use of the word invasion are Democrats? Raise your hand?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: They are coming here with their own flag, flying their own flag. They drew a Swastika. I mean, American flag and burned it in front of the Honduran--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: First--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: It's an invasion. I'm sorry. It's an invasion.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: There are people that fly the Confederate flag today.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry. If that -- let's stay with the equal immigration. I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: No, no. But there are people that fly--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: If you want to come to this country, don't burn our flag.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: There are people that fly the Confederate flag, so you're talking about they are burning our flag.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. All right.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Am I going to have to separate you two?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right. Back row. Hold on. We got to give everybody and everybody a viewpoint here.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: So, in terms of being organized, how is that different than caravans of boats that came over with what we call pilgrims which were simply European refugees, how is that any different when we're talking about caravans and invasions but we're not talking about what is the original in the invasion of this or where we sit? We are in an invaded land that we invaded. Well, not I, not I, right. But

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, I think how many here believe that in part, these caravans have a political motivation in their organization? Raise your hand.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I think so--

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Certainly--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: We're going to get to that. Let's watch. Remember, everybody has to get a point.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I wanted to say something here.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Clyde?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I just wanted to mention harking back to what you said regarding gaming the system and what that gentleman said is probably true. We've been gaming the system ever since we arrived by the Mayflower. That's why I believe we have laws and that's why I think we have the system. I think we do need comprehensive immigration. I got here in 1969, I've been here in the same story over and over and over again. So, I think that we need to take the rule of law and we need to enforce it. And when you said welcome I'm not sure what that means. We're a welcoming country that can vet each and every individual and use the power of the United States of America to keep us the United States of America.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: There was an important thing we learned at the very beginning. This is a half Republican half Democratic group, only one person said they wanted to welcome that caravan.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: It's very interesting the way these Arizona voters are breaking out. This is similar to what I found when we were in Texas last week.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Very similar. Now as you know, President Trump has moved or vowed to move 15,000 troops to the border.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Already moved the initial to Texas, the Texas border which is where most of these migrants will arrive within the next month.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: And President Obama is now responding. We want to play this for you and get your reaction. Watch.

utterances.speaker: BARACK OBAMA, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: They're even taking our brave troops away from their families for a political stunt at the border.

utterances.speaker: OBAMA
utterances.utterance: And the men and women of our military deserve better than that.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Is this a political stunt in your mind. Raise your hand if you believe it's a political stunt.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Hold on. Raise your hand if you believe there is no reason to have the U.S. military on the border and it's purely politics.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It is politics.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right. Hold on. We got to give everybody here a voice.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: yes, sir?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Yes. It is purely politics and I believe this rhetoric is dangerous. I want to go back to the word invasion. We are the greatest country in the entire world and we are scared of a caravan from her folks were coming to seek asylum. I thought that we can have better use of our troops' time and resources. Here in Arizona at any given time where I live in my community we have over 500 homeless youth. One in four children go hungry. I don't feel this is a great way to utilize our nation's resources. And so, again, we have to be very careful when we use the word invasion. I don't see this as an invasion.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: How many people here are aware of the percentage of drugs coming into the country that come through Arizona. Let's have some gases. What percentage of drugs come through Arizona?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Sixty percent.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Six?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Sixty percent.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Forty percent.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Bingo. Forty percent of the drugs coming into the country come through our southern border. The poorest nature of our border.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: But I also don't trust some current law enforcement we have. I don't feel that they need babysitters. We have thousands of border patrol agents.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I have another question for the crowd and then we got to move on to another topic. Another question for the crowd, OK. Here's another question. Do you prefer our military to enforce the borders of other countries which they're doing in Syria and Iraq, on Afghanistan, and mostly in the Middle East or enforcing if necessary the borders of the United States? First question, do you want the military enforcing the borders of other countries or the border of the United States? let's go to--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I'm with the -- totally OK with the military protecting our borders, provided that we were being attacked. I feel like that the nation is crippled in fear right now. I need to party in. Sorry. Everybody is like, just polarized because everybody really bad for everybody is good and there is no in the middle, like Ricardo said the caravan there's a lot of people who are at the border already who walked whatever that are really seeking asylum. So we can't want everybody together--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Does asylum mean--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: -- anyone or the other.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: -- seeking a job in the United States? Is that asylum?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: No. But it's where--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Because that's what most of the people at the caravan want. So, they want to have--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: And I agree. I believe the caravan is like probably a little different. But the--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: No, that's actually not. The caravan is overwhelmingly -- the caravan according to DHS, according to the Mexican and Guatemalan officials there's a lot are great people, a lot of great people there. But overwhelmingly when you -- when they're interviewed, overwhelmingly before their, you know, their coach they're interviewed their said they want to work.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Right, right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And they want their family members are here. I -- and I mean I think a lot of people understand that. It's very different from a systematic, ethnic cleansing, systematic persecution, the Christians in the Middle East are being beheaded, buried alive with their heads. That's a different type of situation. So, we got to be careful with their terminology. Another issue which is as a nation gripped right now is the issue of race. I want to play for this group all of your different backgrounds what is being said lately about President Trump. Let's watch.

utterances.speaker: JOHN HEILEMANN, NATIONAL AFFAIRS ANALYST, MSNBC
utterances.utterance: The president is obviously a racist, he's obviously a demagogue.

utterances.speaker: MIKA BRZEZINSKI, ANCHOR, MSNBC
utterances.utterance: The rhetoric of this racist, heartless, soulless man will lead to more violence. Yes, I said that, and a lot of Americans believe it too.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN HOST
utterances.utterance: To make it appeal to fear and hate is what it is and it is racist. The president has always used fear to his advantage.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Show of hands, how many people think those media appraisals are accurate. One, two, three, four. Who feels they're unfair? Why? Juttia.

utterances.speaker: JULLIA LUNARIO, DEMOCRAT
utterances.utterance: I don't see the president as a person that is a racist. He has shown that he has had many people of difference backgrounds, ethnic everything and I don't think race is the issue. It is, I don't like you. I don't care because--

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: What did I do to you, Juttia?

utterances.speaker: LUNARIO
utterances.utterance: -- because who you are. It doesn't matter of your background whether you were English, German, white, Asian, it doesn't matter. It's constantly used to make this man look bad. Use something different. Try something new.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: How many people here believe that the charge of racism is used too casually in the United States? Raise your hand.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Well, racism is (Inaudible)

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Clyde?

utterances.speaker: CLYDE BOWEN, REPUBLICAN
utterances.utterance: Well, I just think that what you're seeing is the last gasp of desperate group that needs -- that needs votes because that's all the Democrats have. And you notice they are very quiet about Louis Farrakhan. I went to the same school as he did in Boston and I know quite a lot about that gentleman and nothing is said about the things that he has said such as the Jews bring termites. And going back -- I'm sorry. Going back to the original time that he first got started. So, I would say that they're just using that and I'm not saying that. And yes, we've got a president that's kind of a newbie of being a president and he is himself and he is a human being. But I would just say that they just using this is race baiting and race. And if you crack a history book, you would see who very surely is the person who as the guy who in many of the situation concerning race with African-Americans.

utterances.speaker: ROY TATEM, JR., DEMOCRAT
utterances.utterance: If you crack a history book you'll see today was 287 years of slavery based on race. It wasn't based on anything else.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: And propagated by the Democrats and propagated by the Democrats from day one.

utterances.speaker: TATEM
utterances.utterance: Here in America. That is not race. We're not talking political--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And the party -- and the party that--

utterances.speaker: TATEM
utterances.utterance: We're not talking about politics. We're talking about base on--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: TATEM
utterances.utterance: Hold on, hold on, we're talking about base on race. I let them. They're already talk. Can I make my point?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TATEM
utterances.utterance: We're talking about base on race. African-Americans have been enslaved. African-American after slavery in 1865 was subjugated to a 100 years of Jim Crow lynching, disenfranchise men base on race. So, they only say that the only people that are playing race identity politics have no merit. There's a huge merit.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Sorry, Roy.

utterances.speaker: TATEM
utterances.utterance: No, no, there's a huge merit to--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Sorry. OK. Well, she hasn't spoken out.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Also, the Jewish community, too. You cannot--

utterances.speaker: TATEM
utterances.utterance: I'm not talking about -- we're talking about race.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I don't -- she asks a specific question.

utterances.speaker: TATEM
utterances.utterance: We're talking about race.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Laura ask a specific question--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. One at a time.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: OK. Roy, let's give her chance to response.

utterances.speaker: TATEM
utterances.utterance: I'm not negating it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: She ask a specific question about whether Trump and everybody, is he racist. He is not. It is an excuse. There is no proof. There is no background.

utterances.speaker: TATEM
utterances.utterance: Do you know?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, let's just -- let one person speak, guys

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: It's actually -- yes. My good friend Mary Anne Mendoza knows him. Yes, absolutely. Don't -- its not personal.

utterances.speaker: TATEM
utterances.utterance: You're racist.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Roy, this is not personal.

utterances.speaker: TATEM
utterances.utterance: You're racist--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: You're make a convoluted argument when you start bringing slavery.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: They do.

utterances.speaker: TATEM
utterances.utterance: I'm not making a convoluted, I'm giving you the background. I'm giving--

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: OK, one at a time.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. Guys, economic to opportunity in the United States we're to get into this what happened economically and whether that has an effect in making people see things may be a little bit differently, especially Latino communities, African-American communities, Asian communities and how prosperity is rising across the board.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Up next, Trace Gallagher is going to highlight some of the tightest Senate races and then we're going to talk to Arizona Republican senatorial candidate Martha McSally. Stay there.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right. We're just four days away from the midterms and some of these races are in dead heat including right here in Arizona. In moments, we'll talk with Republican Senate candidate Martha McSally. But first, Fox's Trace Gallagher joins us now with an important update. Trace?

utterances.speaker: TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Hi, Laura. If you look at just the Fox News polls over the past two months, the Indiana Senate races is seen a significant shift in the numbers. In September, GOP challenger Mike Braun was up by two points over Democratic incumbent Joe Donnelly. In early October, that flipped and Donnelly was up by two. Now Donnelly has increased the lead to seven points, but don't write off Mike Braun just yet because according to the Real Clear Politics average Donnelly is up by less than one point. Meaning this race still appears to be a dead heat. In the show me state Senate race no matter what poles you look at it is a tossup. The RCP average has Republican challenger Josh Hawley leading by two points over Missouri Democratic incumbent Claire McCaskill and that's within the margin of error. The Fox News poll has them deadlocked at 43 percent each. And it's been that way for the past month. And we should know that polls also show Missouri Democrats appear to be more interested in the election than Missouri Republicans even though 54 percent of likely Missouri voters approve of the president's job performance. The Florida Senate race seems to change with the seasons. For most of the spring Democratic incumbent Senator Bill Nelson held a very steady leave over Florida Republican Governor Rick Scott. Then came summer and Rick Scott took the lead, but now leaves have changed and so have the polls. According to the RCP average, Bill Nelson is back on top by two points. It appears Rick Scott could use a heat wave. Finally, the Arizona where Fox News poll showed Democrat Krysten Sinema and Republican Martha McSally dead even at 46 percent each. That's a bad trend for Sinema who was up by two points in early October and up three in September, although the Real Clear Politics average still has Sinema by just over half point. But all of these polls were taken before Green party candidate Angela Greene dropped out and endorse Krysten Sinema. And we should note Sinema was a green party activist but has tried very hard to distance herself from her past. Laura?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right. Thanks so much, Trace. And joining me now to discuss that latest toss up that Trace just mentioned is a woman vying to become its next senator, Republican Martha McSally, of Arizona. Congresswoman, thanks for being here tonight. I want to start with immigration. We just completed a focus group so important for the voters of the state. How is your view on immigration different from your opponent's? REP. MARTHA MCSALLY, RARIZ.: Well, it's like night and day. I represent a border district. I chair the border security subcommittee and I'm leading working with President Trump to make sure we build the wall, secure the border, close these crazy loopholes that are being taken advantage of every single day, end chain migration, to visa lottery, and you know, move forward in a way that is protecting Americans. My opponent was actually an activist helping people cross illegally in her past and even though she had amazing political makeover trying to fool the voters here, she's voted to support sanctuary cities. And on really important vote here that's meaningful in Arizona is she voted against Grant's Law. This was named after Grant--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Grant Ronnebeck.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.utterance: Yes. And the Angel families have endorsed me just ahead a press conference the other day. She refused to meet with them. Grant was shot point-blank by somebody who shouldn't haven't here and should have been held until they were deported. And that law actually protects people in our community and she refused to vote yes on this. So, she's extreme and out of touch and out of the mainstream--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, she's trying to be a centrist on this. I want to play something for you because she's basically saying I'm just as good as Martha McSally on issues like sending troops to the border. Let's watch.

utterances.speaker: KYRSTEN SINEMA, D, ARIZONA SENATE CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Here in Arizona it's not new for us to have military deployment to the border to provide a support role for our customs and border patrol agents who were down there. So, we wish them well and tell them to stay hydrated.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.utterance: Give me a break. I mean, she has no idea what she's talking about, and she is in the liberal witness protection program right now because border security is so important to all Arizonans. You know, thoughtful Democrat and that's not an oxymoron because, you know, that there are still some who care about safety and security, independence in Republicans. Look, she's extreme on this issue. Look, I am totally support, wholeheartedly support President Trump sending our troops in a support role to secure our border. They support natural disasters. This is a disaster going on in the border.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: She basically says the same thing.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.utterance: Yes. Stay hydrated, right. You know, give me a break. So, look, I welcome to our community. They're coming to Davis-Monthan in Fort Huachuca. I know they are going to do a great job. You know, I served in the military. They are serving and sacrificing. Border security is national security and this is--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Some of our focus group that we just did claim this is all big political stunt.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.utterance: Absolutely not, no, it's not. Look, we have cartels that are trafficking people and drugs through our communities right now. I represent ranchers on the border, they've endorsed me, so are the border patrol agents representing 15,000 agents. They know the dangerous activity that's happening every single day on our border.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Birthright citizenship important issue a lot of Arizona hospitals affected by this migrant families, women come, have their children automatic passport, automatic American citizenship. Your view.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.utterance: Yes. And then we see a Chinese are coming over. There's a whole fraudulent way for them to do that. Look, I appreciate the president is bringing this up and the abuses of it. If we actually secure the border and we actually crackdown on illegal immigration and close these loopholes, we wouldn't even be having these conversations. So, once again, you know, he's highlighting things that are being abused. You know--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Fourteen amendment covered or not in your view?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.utterance: I'm not a constitutional expert. I just think if we secure our border and close these loopholes then we would stop his from happening again.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The migrant lawsuit against President Trump and the administration. It's a, you know, six kids are in it. Six kids and a number of Honduran nationals saying what the president said, in part, I'm mentioning our show. "The legal problem with Trump's plan to stop caravan persons from entering this country that plaintiffs are seeking asylum." And goes on to say, "and Trump simply cannot stop them from legally doing so or using the military or anyone."

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.utterance: You can't make this up. I mean, this is just another example of people trying to take advantage of the weaknesses in our laws that we in Congress need to fix. My bill which you also very strongly supported, often called the Goodlatte bill, that it was the Goodlatte-McSally bill, McCaul and Labrador. We work really hard on this and with President Trump to close these loopholes, to make sure that people can't just show up and demand to be in our country and be released into the interior of the United States. This is happening every single day here in Arizona. Hundreds of little mini caravans are taking advantage of this and now they're trying to sue the president? This has to stop. We must secure our border now.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Are you worried about this Green party Cook now endorsing Sinema. It was pulling about 6 percent. But she's a centrist, but suddenly the Green party person likes the centrist as well?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.utterance: Well, Sinema was actually the Green party activist and first ran for office as Green party ran of Ralph Nader's campaign. So, it actually I think is, you know, a completion of her being identified for who she truly is. This, Angela Green, the Green party candidate was true to herself as a liberal. And the fact that she is getting behind Sinema hopefully should have people wake up and realize Sinema is not a moderate. She's an extreme liberal. She's out of the mainstream and this just brings it back to full circle of where her roots are.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Why is this race so close?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.utterance: Money. Chuck Schumer, George Soros and others have poured tens of millions of dollars into Krysten Sinema to present this image to the Arizona voters that she's actually right of center. It's not true. It's the biggest political cover-up in Arizona history. I just ask people across the country here are listening. If you want to help us make sure we keep this seat. You know, we pick up North Dakota, we don't want to cancel it out in Arizona, right. This is for everybody, not just in Arizona. Please go to McSallyforSenate.com. We need people to contribute. But we need people to get off the sidelines in Arizona. So, tell your friends and family to get out to the polls to make sure that we hold this seat. This is about the direction of our country.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: One to 10 how important is the Trump factor here in Arizona. He's very popular.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.utterance: It's very important. I look at John Junior was out yesterday. You know, President was here a couple of weeks ago. I flew at Marine One. I'm working very closely with him on so many things. We're building our military, securing our border. Look at the economy. I mean, it's amazing. We want to keep things going and that's what this election is about.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Congressman, best of luck.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.utterance: Thanks a lot. We really appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Close it hard for a strong close. And if you like what you saw from the first part of our focus group, stay right there. Up next, the Trump effect.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Illegal immigrant should they get free healthcare in the United States? Raise your hand.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Free healthcare for illegal immigrant?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Well, you'll have to pay through our--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Free college?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Free college.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: As you'd expect, President Donald Trump looms large over these midterms no matter what party you are supporting. What did our focus group think about the so-called "Trump effect?" Watch.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It's 29 percent approval rating now among African-Americans in the latest poll for this president, 29 percent. It was 11 percent, and this is not a conservative poll. This is I believe the Harvard-Harris poll. So that's a significant increase. Why do we think that's happening? And do we think Democrats are freaking out about that?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Yes, they are.

utterances.speaker: ROY TATEM JR., DEMOCRAT
utterances.utterance: I see more reports over a long period of time. Statistics show that people no longer report, or are no longer on the books when they are unemployed for a long period of time. And many African- Americans have experienced long-term unemployment, so they aren't even being counted.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I think the unemployment rate of the African-American community is the lowest it's ever been.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: But he said it's not real, the number is not real.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: That's what he said.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: He's racist.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: He has done more for the Latino and black community than Obama ever did, and I voted for the man. He has done more --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Guys, guys, we have to move on from this topic. But, is -- to close this out, do charges of racism encourage more speech or limit speech? I get the sense that people kind of pull back when the charge is made, that people pull back.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: We just witnessed neo-Nazis marching in Charlottesville.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Tristian?

utterances.speaker: RAYMOND ARROYO, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: You wanted to say something, Tristian.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Tristian?

utterances.speaker: TRISTIAN ROPA, DEMOCRAT
utterances.utterance: I don't feel like people are pulling back at all. We just recently with these last three events that happened just recently. And I don't like to point out this political did this. That's useless and divisive. But we should acknowledge that the guy that sent all these bombs, he did have that van and he was a devout supporter. And then with the shooting in the synagogue, he was a devout supporter.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: No, he wasn't a -- no, no. He was not.

utterances.speaker: ROPA
utterances.utterance: Thank you for correcting me.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And Steve Scalise was almost killed and he was a Bernie Sanders supporter.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: You guys can't dominate.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: We are listening to Tristian.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: We have Tristian is a young person.

utterances.speaker: ROPA
utterances.utterance: And thank you for calling me out on that, for real. Thank you. But still, the climate that we are in right now, people are really willing to do and say these things. And it's not a right or left thing. It's all over the place. I feel like conversation is -- there is a lot of conversation and sometimes it gets really messy. And honestly, that's sad.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: How many people here, so of hands, will race affect your vote in this midterm election? Is race important to you and the way it's been depicted.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And your vote.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: And your vote.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK, we have got to move on guys. I want to get into the idea that this election -- many people are saying it's a referendum on President Trump. So regardless of which party you are voting for, is there anyone here only voting on Tuesday as a pro or anti-Trump sentiment? Raise your hand. Is it about Trump for you on Tuesday? Raise your hand. OK.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: As a Democrat.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I'm not.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: You're not a Democrat.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: She's an independent.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: You're an independent.

utterances.speaker: RAYMOND ARROYO, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: You're paying back now, aren't you?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The current economy today is at the strongest it's been in my lifetime. There's never been a better time to be a small business owner, to be entering the workforce for the first time, never a better time. Today the news came out, 3.5 percent, wage increase which is the largest we've had since 2009. Unemployment is down to a 1967 low which is fantastic across all economic strata. How many of you here today give Trump credit for this economic revival on the wage increase? Raise you hand. You haven't spoken, another young person. I want to hear from the youth.

utterances.speaker: TEANA LONG, DEMOCRAT
utterances.utterance: I go to school up north. I'm in a small town. And the wage increases have really affected our small town, because, like I said, it's very small. So it's really hard not only to find jobs because small businesses can't afford to pay its workers, but it's really hard -- a lot of companies are going out of business and we are losing a lot of really valuable companies that are really important to our market.

utterances.speaker: DEBE CAMPOS FLEENOR, REPUBLICAN
utterances.utterance: I am a small business owner, Latino owned, woman owned, and actually the taxes from Trump have done very well for our small business.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Tax cuts?

utterances.speaker: FLEENOR
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What have they resulted in?

utterances.speaker: FLEENOR
utterances.utterance: Right here, $1,200. So that's pretty good. It gives me the opportunity to pay my employees the wage increase that was forced upon me, instead of cutting hours.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: How many Democrats here, those of you who are Democrats, are you concerned that the House of Representatives being turned over to Democrats would upset the economic recovery? Raise your hand. Even if you voted Democrat, are you concerned about the economy being adversely affected?

utterances.speaker: PILAR RUIZ, DEMOCRAT
utterances.utterance: I am. From southern Arizona, I'm a neighbor with Raul Grijalva, district three. And that is one of the poorest districts in the country. And he is a Democrat and I am a Democrat, but you know what, for me it's not always about party line. It's about what are you doing for the people. And him and his daughter have hurt southern Arizona, Adelita Grijalva, more than any other politicians in Arizona in my opinion. So that regards, I don't want that man in office. We need Republican in district three to win that race because -- I know it's not going to happen but it needs to happen because that district is extremely poor. There is no economic growth. There is no nothing.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: How many of you here will miss Jeff Flake? Raise your hand. How many of you here will miss Jeff Flake in the U.S. Senate?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Only his sanity.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: He has about an 18 percent approval rating, but that's OK. While we are talking about Arizona, this is what Kyrsten Sinema, of course the Democrat who wants to be your next senator, said about the state she hopes to represent. Let's listen.

utterances.speaker: KYRSTEN SIMENA, (D-AZ) SENATE CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: So all around the world people know what's happening in Arizona, and not in a good way. We're not famous in a good way. We're kind of like in a Lindsay Lohan kind of famous way. The states are the laboratories of democracies, and in my state of Arizona it's clearly the meth lab of democracy. Republicans get a free ride when they call the Tea Party something other than what they are. And we have to say no, no, Tea Party Republicans, all the same thing. They're all crazy.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: To the Democrats in the room, put your hands up. If that offends you in any way.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It depends. I couldn't really hear it very well. I have a lot of disagreements with Kyrsten Sinema over the years, and I'm not a good friend of hers, but she is 10 times better than McSally on issues right from the top to the bottom.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Now, the further removed we are from the Kavanaugh confirmation fight, the more the baseless charges against him unravel. Ann Coulter is here, she will be with us later, to tell us about another criminal referral involving a Kavanaugh accuser. And up next, when Hollywood comes out to stump for Democrats, does anyone care? And wait until you hear what our focus group tells us. Don't go anywhere.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: It probably will put a fire under me, especially with all the misogyny going on.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The Democratic candidates are bringing out the big guns. Celebrities are making ads, knocking on doors, as White House pushes back.

utterances.speaker: OPRAH WINFREY, TALK SHOW HOST
utterances.utterance: You get a vote, and you get a vote, and you get a vote.

utterances.speaker: WILL FERRELL, ACTOR
utterances.utterance: Hi. It's Will Ferrell. I'm here in Kennesaw State. Of course home of the owls. We're trying to get people to vote here for Stacey Abrams.

utterances.speaker: MIKE PENCE, U.S. VICE PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: I would like to remind Stacey and Oprah and Will Ferrell, I'm kind of a big deal, too. This ain't Hollywood. This is Georgia.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK, so does trotting out Hollywood heavyweights actually move voters? We asked our focus group. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: How many people here in Arizona would you have your vote affected one way or the another by a celebrity's endorsement? Raise your hand. No one, either side.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Alex, you are one of the people they are targeting, young people. Your reaction to that?

utterances.speaker: ALEX PHILLIPS, REPUBLICAN
utterances.utterance: As much fun as I had seen Kanye West and Donald Trump in the White House --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIPS
utterances.utterance: -- with the hats on, I'm not going to base my political views off that. You can get your mileage off of it, but at the end of the day you should probably not make that the be-all, end-all.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Take a look at this brand-new political ad directed by a brilliant film director and actress, Jodie Foster.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: If somebody asked you what do you care about, what would you say?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Losing your health care?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Equal pay?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Equal rights?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: What really, honestly matter to you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: If basic human rights matter, then vote.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: If women's rights really are human rights, then vote.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Don't.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Lose.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Hope.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: To the ladies here, would that ad in any way motivate you to go to the polls? Show of hands. Yes, if it would. In the back, why?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: If I wasn't going to vote or had no motivation, it would probably put a fire under me, especially with all the misogyny going on.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What is the most important issue for all of you, both parties, no parties, on Tuesday, the most important issue?

utterances.speaker: PATRICK BRAY, REPUBLICAN
utterances.utterance: I think for Arizona in general right now, I think the top issue is clearly immigration. And it's driven by the caravan that is on his way here. And I think we talked about it, but there's a twofold there with immigration. There is the regulatory system that's broken, but there's a border security issue that's also broken, and that's why you have to see the military making sure we send a clear signal that we are just not going to let people in our back door.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Health care for all. That's the biggest issue. People need -- how many -- 35 million people are without health care.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Should illegal immigrants, should they get free health care in the United States? Raise your hand.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. Well, you'll have to pay for it through --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Free college?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Free college.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right, let's go. You better make a lot of money.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: How many people support that idea, free college, free health care for illegal immigrants.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Do African-Americans or veterans all get free college? We have 300,000 veterans living on the street, homeless veterans on the street tonight.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: There are 60 percent taxes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Medicare for all is not free. I'm on Medicare.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: There won't be any Medicare dollars for you, my friend.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's not free.

utterances.speaker: FLEENOR
utterances.utterance: -- of us are working to pay taxes. We are supporting those people whether they are illegal or whatever. I can't work anymore. I can't pay any more taxes. And 47 percent are on the dole. And how much greater does that number need to go before we become a socialist --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Hold on, guys. While we're talking about that, birthright citizenship, should children born -- neither parent is an American citizen, neither parent is here illegally as a worker or anything like that, but just illegal immigrant in the United States has a child. Should that child immediately become an American citizen?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Of course, it's the 14th Amendment.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's in the Constitution.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So all -- so 300,000 of the illegal immigrants should automatically become --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right, it got really raucous there. We could have done a whole on this. I want to do more of these, so much fun. Another Kavanaugh accuser, by the way, facing potentially severe criminal punishment over a false claim against the now associate justice of the Supreme Court. Ann Coulter is here next to break it all down, and what it could mean for the midterms.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Brett Kavanaugh might be sitting on the Supreme Court, but the fallout from his confirmation battle is far from over. Just hours ago, Senator Chuck Grassley made another criminal referral to the Department of Justice concerning an unnamed accuser who made rape allegations against Kavanaugh. The unidentified woman admits she, quote, "just wanted to get attention," and that it was, quote, "a ploy." And joining me now with her reaction is bestselling author and commentator Ann Coulter. Ann, the convention here is that Republican enthusiasm over the Kavanaugh confirmation was waning. What do you think with stories like this in the last few days before the vote?

utterances.speaker: ANN COULTER, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR
utterances.utterance: Liberals are crazy, and it's good for voters to be reminded of this. We've been going through a two-year tantrum. But this one really takes the cake. That letter she wrote reads like, Penthouse letters, the detail of this gang rape. And first it's just written anonymously. The handwriting could have been written by a man. It's sort of suspicious, a lot of capital letters. It's like a hostage note. And then this woman in Kentucky claims that she was the one who wrote it, gives her name. The Senate Judiciary Committee does a little research and finds out she doesn't live either in Washington, D.C., or Oceanside, California, which is where the original anonymous hostage letter claimed to come from. She's from Kentucky. She's and several decades older than judge, not justice Kavanaugh, and has a history of being a liberal activist. Her quotes to the committee were hilarious. It was just, yes, well, it was in the news. I wanted to get attention. He had to be stopped.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Ann, isn't this good, though, to make these people pay? And it reminds me of this leak that came out of the Feinstein office. I've been talking about this since it happened. This must be investigated and it must be pursued. Republicans are going to hold onto the House, unless something really wacky happens. This can't be dropped by Lindsey Graham when he takes over the committee. I think you've got to go in. I want everybody's emails, I want everybody's texts, and I want to know who leaked that Blasey Ford letter. I want to know who did that. It was a travesty what happened to him.

utterances.speaker: COULTER
utterances.utterance: Yes. What often happens in these cases is our side, OK, he's on the Supreme Court, let's move on. Let's be good guys, because that will be repaid by good behavior from the left. No, we will never get good behavior from the left. And whether it's a Duke lacrosse or that UVA gal or mattress girl up in Columbia, there have just been all of these fake rate allegations, which happen to be the fake allegations made against judge, now Justice Kavanaugh. And the false accuser doesn't get prosecuted. In the Duke lacrosse case, she went on to stop her boyfriend to death. No, there has to be some sort of repercussions of making false allegations of rape. This was a very serious allegation, not particularly plausible. But of course these cases need to be pursued. One other thing, I think this is why contrary to what everybody else will be telling President Trump, the next nominee he gets to the Supreme Court, I don't care whom he is replacing, it has to be a man because we now know what the left's playbook is. They did at 29 years ago to Justice Thomas, they did it again to now to Justice Kavanaugh. People are going to say, pick a woman, pick a woman. What, because liberal love women so much? They love you and me, Laura, they love Sarah Palin.

utterances.speaker: COULTER
utterances.utterance: But if they have another false allegation, I don't think anybody is going to buy it in the next few years. It absolutely should be a man.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I think it should be the best, I don't care what your gender is, the best and most conservative, judicially conservative pick, whoever that is. But doing the bean counting, Ann, never works for conservatives. You've been way ahead of the curve on that issue, and obviously immigration and so many others. Thank you so much, Ann Coulter, here on the "The Laura Ingraham Show and on the "Ingraham Angle," of course. I still have radio on the brain. When we come back, a preview of my Monday night closing argument, next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Martha McSally, good luck. You're going to be singing the national anthem tomorrow at the ASU football game. I'll be there. I'll be watching. And her opponent Kyrsten Sinema is going to be taking part in the coin toss. And on Monday, I'm going to deliver my closing arguments to all you voters across the country.
